transcript:
Patient: I appreciate your guidance, Nova. It's helpful to have a plan for managing those feelings of worthlessness when they come up. I know it'll take time and practice to really internalize this new core belief.

Therapist: You're absolutely right, Jamie. Changing long-held beliefs is a process, and it's normal to have moments where those old beliefs resurface. The key is to recognize when it's happening and use the tools we've discussed to challenge those thoughts and reinforce your new, more adaptive belief.

As we're nearing the end of our session today, I want to check in with you about how you're feeling now. Has anything we've discussed today shifted your perspective or given you new insights?

Patient: I'm feeling a bit more hopeful after our conversation. It's comforting to know that I have strategies to use when those negative thoughts come up. I know it won't be easy, but I feel like I have a plan now.

Therapist: That's wonderful to hear, Jamie. Remember, progress isn't always linear, and there will be ups and downs along the way. The important thing is to keep practicing these skills and be patient with yourself.

For homework this week, I'd like you to continue working on the thought records, focusing on challenging those negative core beliefs and gathering evidence for your new, more adaptive belief. I also encourage you to create that list of evidence we discussed, so you have it readily available when you need it. Finally, let's set a goal for you to engage in at least one self-care activity each day, even if it's something small.

Patient: That sounds like a good plan. I'll keep working on the thought records and create that list of evidence. And I'll try to do at least one self-care activity each day, even if it's just taking a short walk or spending a few minutes journaling.

Therapist: Excellent, Jamie. Remember, self-care doesn't have to be time-consuming or complicated. Even small actions can make a big difference in your overall well-being.

In our next session, we'll review your progress with the homework and discuss any challenges or successes you've had. We'll also continue working on strengthening that new core belief and exploring any other negative thoughts or beliefs that may be impacting your mood.

Patient: That sounds good. I'm looking forward to continuing our work together.

Therapist: I'm looking forward to it as well, Jamie. You're making great progress, and I'm confident that with continued practice, you'll start to see even more improvements in your mood and overall well-being.

Before we wrap up, do you have any final thoughts or questions you'd like to discuss today?

Patient: No, I think we've covered a lot of ground today. I appreciate your support and guidance, Nova.

Therapist: It's my pleasure, Jamie. Remember, I'm here to support you every step of the way. If any challenges or questions come up between now and our next session, don't hesitate to reach out.

Take care, and I'll see you next week.

Session Summary:
- Main topics discussed: Developing more adaptive core beliefs, strategies for managing feelings of worthlessness when they arise, importance of self-care in building emotional resilience.
- Techniques or exercises used: Thought records, challenging negative core beliefs, creating a list of evidence against negative beliefs, planning self-care activities. In previous sessions, we have also used examining the evidence for and against negative thoughts, considering the costs and benefits of perfectionistic beliefs, behavioral experiments, loving-kindness meditation, activity scheduling, and graded task assignments. We will continue to build on these techniques in future sessions, with a focus on applying them to specific challenges and situations in Jamie's life.
- Homework assigned: 1) Continue working on thought records, focusing on challenging negative core beliefs and gathering evidence for new, more adaptive beliefs; 2) Create a list of evidence against negative core beliefs to refer to when needed; 3) Engage in at least one self-care activity each day, even if it's something small.
- Patient's progress, challenges, depression symptoms and important personal details: Jamie is making progress in developing more adaptive core beliefs and recognizing the flaws in their negative beliefs. They are starting to see the connections between thoughts, feelings, and behaviors and are taking steps to challenge negative thoughts and engage in self-care. Jamie's perfectionism and self-criticism remain challenges that contribute to their depression and anxiety.
- Core beliefs and intermediate beliefs: In this session, we focused on challenging Jamie's negative core belief of being worthless and undeserving of happiness or success and developing a more adaptive belief: "I have value and am capable of achieving happiness and success, even though I face challenges." We have not explicitly discussed intermediate beliefs yet, but based on Jamie's struggles with perfectionism and self-criticism, it's likely that they hold beliefs such as "I'm not good enough" or "I have to be perfect to be worthy of love and acceptance." We will continue to explore these beliefs in future sessions.
- Important information to carry forward: Jamie's specific goals and treatment plan, their struggles with insomnia, negative self-talk, and perfectionism, and their commitment to completing homework and reporting back on progress. Jamie's support system, including their LGBTQ+ support group and trusted friend.
- Plan for the next session: Review Jamie's homework and progress, discuss any challenges or successes, continue building skills in thought records, behavioral activation, distress tolerance techniques, and challenging cognitive distortions, and explore intermediate beliefs related to perfectionism and self-worth.
